newsitem.title: GREECE: Greece critical of Turkey-northern Cyprus accord.
newsitem.headline: Greece critical of Turkey-northern Cyprus accord.

text.p: Greece on Thursday described an accord aimed at the partial integration of northern Cyprus with Turkey as blackmail, saying such moves only distance Ankara from its aspirations in Europe.

"The European Union has stressed that resolving the Cyprus issue is a pre-condition for Turkey's European path," Deputy Foreign Minister George Papandreou told reporters. "Turkey should know such moves clearly do not contribute to its European direction."
The agreement signed on Wednesday calls for an Association Council to work towards the partial economic and defence integration of Turkey with the breakaway Turkish Cypriot state.

The internationally recognised Cypriot government in the south has dismissed the accord, saying it was aimed at provoking Cyprus to boycott U.N.-sponsored talks next week on ways of resolving the conflict splitting the Mediterranean island.
But Greece reacted more strongly, accusing Turkey of undermining the peace talks and trying to stop Cyprus from joining the EU.
Ankara has said it will unite the north with Turkey if accession talks begin next year between the Greek Cypriot-led government and the EU, which now numbers 15 members, including Greece.

"This is sheer blackmail by Ankara against the European Union but Cyprus's accession cannot be obstructed by such blackmail," Greek Defence Minister Akis Tsohatzopoulos was quoted as saying by the semi-official Athens News Agency.
"It is not Greece but Turkey who is damaged by such fireworks," he added.

Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders are due to meet in Montreux, Switzerland, on Monday, for a second round of talks aimed at reviving negotiations to reunite the island, which has been divided since Turkey occupied its northern third in 1974.
The Turkish Cypriot state in the north was declared in 1983 and is recognised only by Ankara.
